Hi and welcome
to 'This Is My Architecture'.

I'm with Mario from Syntax today;
thank you, Mario.
Thank you for inviting me.

So can you please tell us a little bit more
about Syntax and your solution?

Syntax is a global technology
provider of solutions,
and also application managed services;

with more than 50 years in the market
and more than 700 customers being served.

We serve mission critical
environments such SAP or Oracle.
We are also Amazon Premier Partners,

with the competencies of migrations, SAP,
Oracle, managed services and DevOps.

I see SAP and I see different AWS services,
so how do they interact in your solution?
Yeah.

SAP customers have been extracting data
out of the SAP environments for many years,

but modern requirements
from the SAP customers

will make them
need to communicate

SAP with Amazon Services
in terms of machine learning,
IoT, or analytical capability tools.

So extracting that data out of
SAP environments is a little bit complicated,
it always has been complicated,

and SAP also provided
tools for doing that,

but many customers fell themselves
into silos of analytical tools surrounding SAP.
So we created an add-on,

which is essentially
an ABAP SDK for Amazon Services,
which runs on the application layer of SAP.

So it's installed and it's based
on the ABAP language,
and it runs on SAP environments

which enables SAP
to communicate with Amazon services
in the native SAP language called ABAP.

So how does this plug-in interact;
what is the workflow?

So imagine one SAP customer
that will have different sources of data.

These sources of data
can be an SAP CRM, an SAP HR

- another SAP environment -or another database,
or any other of the SAP sources of data.

And they would like to consolidate
that data into an SAP environment,

or have an SAP environment
generating a big load of that data.

That environment can be used
to communicate from a single source

to the Amazon Services by using
one single installation of this particular tool.

So when you extract it out,
how do you collect them on AWS?

So as part of the SDK we provide the capability
to talk to several Amazon services.

We focus on Amazon S3 and Kinesis
Data Streams for this particular use case.

So when the customers are extracting
data out of the SAP environment,

we encourage them to use
one SAP software called SLT.
SLT is an ABAP-based ETL,

built natively
into modern SAP environments

which will enable us to use
the application layer capabilities
to extract data from our SAP environments

directly into Amazon S3
or Amazon Kinesis data streams
in real-time with a high volume of flow, too.

Okay, that's great; but I still see
two additional AWS Services,

so if you can mention
how do you interact with them?

Yeah. When the customers are extracting
data out of the SAP environments,

imagine that we are going to have
a big portion of data in the Amazon service.

So once these solutions
are built or put together
customers start having for example,
more than 700,000 records per minute
generated into Amazon S3
with more than 90 sources of data;

you can easily have more
than 500 million records per hour
created on AWS.

So one of the services where
we enable the communication,

the native communication
from SAP to Amazon,
is also SNS or Lambda services.

This enables customers that once
the data has been created into Amazon

we can call additional services
using Lambda functions

to for example,
create a Parquet set of data
using the S3 as a source.

So you can add any further,
say data transformation
and customize it on Lambda, so that's great.

And as you wrote down this number,
something I really appreciate

is that we don't need - you don't need
a middleware within AWS and SAP;
it's all native so on the application layer

you can scale up and reach
this great number as well.
Correct, SAP has several extraction methods.

The application layer
for us and for our customers
is what it's being leveraged at most

because it allows us to abstract
from their underlying database.

This solution is SAP Certified to run
on ECC and or S/4HANA environment.

S/4HANA environment
on an SAP database called HANA,

but the ECC environment
can run on Oracle or SQL Server.

So using this tool we abstract
whatever the database the customer is using

so it will enable any customer
to do the same solution

for any SAP environment
where they might particularly be
of their interest.

Well that's great.
So what's coming next?

Is there any additional feature
you are let's say, working on at the moment?

Yeah, in the future we will enable
the Amazon Service EventBridge,

which will help us to close
with Kinesis and with SNS and SQS

the events architecture
out of the SAP environment.

So customers - any SAP customers - which will
like to play with the publish and subscribe

out of their SAP data will be able to use
the Amazon Services available in the market.

Oh, that's great! So next time
we will have additional items

let's say, to show
and talk about.

So thank you, thank you
for sharing this great architecture today.
Thank you for having me.

Thank you for watching
'This Is My Architecture'.
